story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council has recognised a group of inspirational young people at its sixth annual YAFTA Awards.The event, which was a celebration of a programme between the Youth Council and Newry, Mourne and Down Council, took place at the Canal Court Hotel and Spa recently.The glamorous event saw  people celebrate both the young people and the projects they are involved in.Council chairman Mark Murnin said he was delighted to celebrate the achievements of ldquoour outstanding young people.He remarked: ldquoThe YAFTAS were specically created by the youth council and supported by the council and the Education Authority to recognise the unsung heroes of within our community who do not get the recognition they deserve.ldquoThese awards shine a positive light on our young people and the work they do.He added: ldquoThe competition this year made shortlisting winners more dficult as our young people across the district have been involved in some fantastic youth work programmes, including volunteering.ldquoBoth the young people and their achievements deserve to be highlighted and recognised.There were seven award categories recognising dferent aspects of community and voluntary service.The Voice of Young People Award went to Cathal McCann, Emma Cunningham and Brooklyn Flanagan, three pupils from St Malachyrsquos High School in Castlewellan.These three students wanted to do more to raise awareness of student emotional wellbeing. They came up with the idea to host a fundraising event within their school involving students wearing a bright jumper to school on Blue Monday, January .They raised pound which went to supporting early intervention strategies towards young people. As a result, these students appeared in a video which was created by Action for Children and was shown to MPs and MLAs at Stormont to raise awareness of mental health issues towards young people and the need for extra government funding.The runner-up in this category was Lara OrsquoNeill, Head Girl at St Maryrsquos High School in Newry.The Innovation and Creativity Award category was won by the Slurrysafe team of Conal Murray, Matthew Isaac and Connor Kelly, from South Eastern Regional College in Downpatrick.The boys, all from farming backgrounds met at an engineering course and decided to tackle the risks associated from slurry by designing a slurry alarm after an incident affected one of their families.Their design dfers by linking the alarm to the tractor engine so that when the alarm sounds, power to the tractor is cut off which stops the slurry mixer. This alerts the farmer and a sensor sends a message to a mobile phone of the risk.The runners-up in this category were Assumption Community Link mdash students at Assumption Grammar School who have been innovative in establishing a community link with local primary schools in the Ballynahinch area.They have supported children in the local area who have high levels of illiteracy and innumeracy and struggle with socio-economic hardship. They provided taster sessions in Irish and Spanish when the primary schools were informed funding for languages was no longer available.A third dimension of the community link is the partnership with Knockevin Special School in Downpatrick where they work in the areas of music and drama.The Inspirational Young Person Award went to Cormac Savage, from Downpatrick, is a student at St Patrickrsquos Grammar School where he has been involved in civic education and getting students involved in the democratic process.Cormac has co-ordinated the Make Your Mark Campaign in South Down, a youth campaign that decided on what issues the Youth Parliament should campaign on. Cormac contacted school principals directly and single handedly secured involvement from five principals and over , local students.Cormac went on to represent , young people as a member of the Youth Parliament with % of the vote. He delivered a speech on the subject of homelessness which was awarded the Paul Boskett MBE Award. Cormac is a volunteer at his Mid Down MS support group and assists with Loughinisland amateur drama group, coaching young children in drama. This summer Coramac is planning to travel to Cambodia for three weeks to teach English, plant trees and build homes in some of the poorest communities in the world.In the Young Carer Award category the runners-up were Downpatrick sisters Antonia and Aoise OrsquoGoan, who look after their grandmother, Mrs Margaret Walsh.Other recipients on the night were as follows:Good Relations Award: winners, Leaders of Hope and Harmony, Kilkeel runners-up, Newtownhamilton TBUC in the Community, Newtownhamilton.Young Carer Award: winner, Ben McGlade, Newry.Community Safety Award: winner, Regener, Slieve Gullion runners-up, Newry Fire Cadets.Inspirational Young Person Award: runner-up, Hannah Kelly, Newry.Inclusion Award: winners, Wonder Youth Group and Newry Youth Forum runners-up, St. Oliver Plunkett Inclusion Group, Crossmaglen.The event was supported by Newry, Mourne and Down District Council, the Executive Office, the Policing and Community Safety Partnership, Specsavers Newry, Education Authority, Education Authority Small Grants, Buttercrane Centre Newry, Newry Clinic PJ OrsquoHarersquos, Carlingford and JP Corry..prettyPhoto

title: Irish government urged to support the Patrician story
story: THE Irish government has been urged to do more to support the Patrician story, not only locally, but across the island.The call was issued by Downpatrick Sinn Fein election candidate Oonagh Hanlon during a visit to the town last week by Taacutenaiste Simon Coveney.He was at the St Patrickrsquos Centre to launch local historian John Killenrsquos new book rsquoThe St Patrickrsquos Treasuryrsquo.Mr Hanlon said Mr Coveney clearly has an interest in Patrician history and the contemporary signicance of St Patrick.She said she was keen to stress to Irelandrsquos deputy head of government that the southern administration has a responsibility to support the protection and enhancement of Patrician history throughout Ireland and locally across St Patrickrsquos Country.ldquoWhilst the Taacutenaistersquos department is supportive of a small number of local programmes, I believe it can do much more to help sustain the huge international interest in Patrician history and the signicance of his contemporary inclusive legacy in our ided society, said Mrs Hanlon.She added: ldquoI look forward to continuing this discussion with the Taacutenaiste in the months ahead and thank him for taking time out of a very busy schedule to engage with local school children, business owners and the wider community in Downpatrick..prettyPhoto

title: Irish Street work delay a ‘disgrace’%2C says Curran
story: THE major delay in completing work on an environmental improvement scheme in Irish Street in Downpatrick has been branded a ldquodisgrace by a local politician.Councillor Dermot Curran has this week called for an urgent meeting to be arranged between traders and senior officials from a number of government departments involved in the project to discuss what went wrong and what can be done to ensure the project is completed as soon as possible.Last week the Recorder revealed that Irish Street traders are furious that work on the project is to take more than twice as long to complete than originally planned.Work to provide new paving, street lighting and street furniture was due to complete at the end of March, but contractors will not now be finished their work until the end of June.And, to compound tradersrsquo frustration, once contractors move off site, Irish Street will be completely closed to traffic for a short period to allow the main road to be resurfaced, taking the scheme into July.There have been a series of issues associated with the regeneration scheme with the initial start date delayed as Phoenix Gas took longer than expected to complete its work at this part of the town.Signicant issues have also arisen with the foundations for the blast wall which surrounded the former police base and problems with the sewer network.Cllr Curran wants senior representatives from Newry, Mourne and Down Council and the Departments for Infrastructure and Communities to meet with traders and insists that NI Water must also be represented.ldquoThe public realm scheme has been delayed by over three months, raw sewage has been running down the street and, most shockingly, traders have not been kept abreast of the reasons for the delay, he declared.ldquoThe Irish Street project was due to complete inside three months but it will now be early July and what those responsible for the work do not realise is that businesses are being affected across the town, not just those in Irish Street.Cllr Curran said the delay in completing the scheme is having a major impact on the town centre, revealing that he has heard reports that the number of people using the Irish Street car park has reduced since work on the public realm scheme started.He said with trading conditions dficult enough at the best of times, the last thing business owners need is for the one-way system remaining in place in Irish Street for another two months.ldquoThe delay in completing this scheme is nothing short of disgraceful and questions need answered. In addition, traders should be provided with weekly progress briefings as a matter of courtesy. The fact this has not happened is deeply disappointing, Cllr Curran continued.The local politician said the temporary one-way system is impacting on traffic volumes in St Patrickrsquos Avenue and Market Street in particular, with some shoppers opting to avoid Downpatrick as work on the public realm scheme continues.Cllr Curran also suggested that the delay in delivering the public realm scheme would ldquosimply not be tolerated in any other area. He claimed that taking twice as long to complete a scheme would not be accepted in areas like Newry, Lisburn or Belfast.He declared: ldquoMany businesses in Downpatrick are suffering as the result of an unacceptable delay. The clear evenings are now here, so why canrsquot contractors be asked to work longer to complete the scheme sooner ldquoWhile I accept that the delays may be the result of unexpected circumstances, surely the trick is to come up with imaginative solutions to get the work completed as soon as possible  The suggested completion date at the end of June needs to be reassessed now.Cllr Curran said he plans to contact the ious government departments and agencies to arrange a meeting with Irish Street traders and hopes it will take place as soon as possible..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle park needs management strategy
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council officials have been asked to develop a management strategy for an open area at the rear of Newcastlersquos Donard Park and adjacent woodland.The request has been made by Mournes councillor Willie Clarke, who recently tabled a council motion urging the local authority to contact the Annesley Estate with a view to leasing land it owns at this part of the town.Cllr Clarke is keen for this to happen to enable the council to maintain what he described as an ldquoattractive area to complement existing amenities in Donard Park.He believes the council can help play a key role in improving the recreational, health and well-being of local people, in tandem with enhancing the resortrsquos tourism potential,the area and its important habitat are managed properly.While his recent motion was referred to the local authorityrsquos Economic Regeneration and Tourism Committee for debate, Cllr Clarke said that,re-elected, one of his key priorities will be shaping the future management of a ldquo fabulous landscape and woodland, preserving it for future generations.He continued: ldquoThe upper green area needs to be incorporated in the future management of Donard Wood, while the pathways and signage for visitors need to be improved for visitors entering the main route used by hill walkers heading into the Mournes to climb Slieve Donard.ldquoIn the short term, I have made representations to council officials to carry out maintenance improvements at the Shanslieve Drive entrance to Donard Park where visitors are greeted by rusting litter bins, council signage dating back to the s and a potholed surface.Cllr Clarke said these are improvements that need to carried out immediately.Also this week, he has called on the local authority to repaint the historic archway at the entrance to Donard Park car park.He said: ldquoRepainting the archway will also improve the appearance and aesthetics of the entrance into Donard Park and I have requested that the work is undertaken as quickly as possible, Cllr Clarke added..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle rock star’s intimate solo album
story: THE discovery of a random white feather gave The Answerrsquos frontman Cormac Neeson a sign of hope at the most desperate time in his le mdash and the inspiration for his first solo album.The Newcastle rocker has just released a searingly intimate and personal album called White Feather with ten tracks which deal with his eldest son Dabhoacutegrsquos fight to be born and for le itself.Launching at Belfast venue The Black Box on May , the  year-old will give his most stripped back performance as an artist as he tours with the album over the coming months.His old friends, The Unholy Gospel Band, with bass guitarist, Downpatrickrsquos own Eamon Hanlon, will be joining him for the big night.Cormac also has a new single out from the album, Broken Wing, a country-inspired track with blues backing choir that will resonate with people whether they are a parent or not.His rock vocals have given way to a deeper, introspective sound that is still etched with emotion.The  year-old singer, who once toured with rock legends AD DC, says he the experience of nearly losing his son from being born prematurely at  weeks has changed him.Dabhoacuteg, who has Downrsquos Syndrome, weighed only lb oz when he was born. After spending his first four months in a hospital neo-natal unit and undergoing heart surgery on his first birthday, he is now four. Thankfully, Dabhoacuteg has turned the corner despite overcoming serious medical obstacles in his short le.Dabhoacuteg and his  month-old brother, Conall, mean everything to Cormac and his we Louise, who now live in Belfast.ldquoWhenever you have a sick child and you go through an ordeal like that with your family, it does definitely alter your perception and you come out the other side of it changed, said Cormac.ldquoYou just look at le in a dferent way. You appreciate stuff that you never appreciated because yoursquore not sitting in an intensive care unit in the Royal [Victoria Hospital]. Anything is better than that.The couple only had a few weeks to privately celebrate getting pregnant with their first child when Louise had to be rushed into hospital.They initially were advised that pregnancy was lost as it was so early but were told to come back to hospital in a few weeks time.ldquoIt was the longest two weeks in my le, recalls Cormac. ldquoThe night before we were due to go the hospital I went out for a walk in the Mournes. I was a bit raging at the world and screaming up to the heavens asking to be give a sign that everything was going to be ok.ldquoI was literally stopped dead in my tracks with this little splash of white high in a tree. I climbed up into the tree to see what it was and it was a white feather.ldquoI had always been brought up to believe that white feathers symbolised new le. I couldnrsquot believe that I spotted it at that time and brought it back down. I had a feeling then that everything was ok. The next day we went to hospital and sure enough there was this tiny mustard seed on the scan with the most giant heartbeat you ever saw in your le. It was the beginning of what was to be a most tumultuous journey and the beginning of where we are now, having an amazing four-year-old and a baby.ldquoDabhoacuteg really is a warrior. Hersquos been through more than me and most people ever will in their lives.Long-term fans of The Answer may be surprised at one of their leaders heading to Nashville to write and record the album.But as Cormac tells it, itrsquos just the way it was meant to be.He went to the home of country music in  on a songwriting course to help write songs for other artists but ended up literally pouring his heart and pain out in the songs mdash in time-honoured country music fashion.ldquoItrsquos not a country record but you can tell it is recorded in Nashville, said Cormac.ldquoThere is an awful lot of soul to it and a bit of subtley to it as well as it allowed me to express myself in the way that I needed to at this point in my le. I needed to make a record that reflected that switch in the way I see le.The Nashville approach to writing songs was a more reflective experience for Cormac that what he is used to with bandmates Paul Mahon, Mickey Waters and James Heatley.ldquoIt was just a completely dferent approach to songwriting that I had been used to doing for  years with The Answer, said Cormac. ldquoItrsquos a hard rocking blues band and a lot of our songs are written with the volume pedal turned up rfing away, having a good time and letting songs organically develop.ldquoIn Nashville, you sit in a room with two other people and an accustic guitar and you have a long conversation about your le and what you might want to write about. I found once we were locked into the message we wanted to put across in the song everything  fell into place. We basically wrote songs in the morning and recorded in the afternoon as thatrsquos what the studio expected.ldquoA lot of what Irsquom singing about on this record just would not work on a record from The Answer because it wouldnrsquot be appropriate. Rock and roll is loud and le-affirming. While a lot of these songs are le-affirming, they are in a completely dferent way.Cormac assures the bandrsquos devoted following that they have stockpiled a supply of new songs and will be coming out with a new album.Addressing his own personal hiatus, Cormac added: ldquoIrsquom still the same guy I was in The Answer and will be again when The Answer makes our next record. I just needed to get into the right room with the right writers making the right music.White Feather album will be released on April  before a tour kicks off in the UK on May  for a run of seven support shows followed by six Irish headline dates. For show dates visit http:www.cormacneeson or https:www.facebook cormacneesonsolo ..prettyPhoto

title: School of Lifesaving staff complete Makaton course
story: DOWNPATRICK School of Lesaving has been taking part in a new training course.Rhianna Rooney and Yvonne Smyth, who are both senior lesaving teachers at Downpatrick School of Lesaving, attended a Full Makaton for Beginners Course held recently in Castlewellan.Aware of how beneficial the use of Makaton could be to the coaches of DSL, Yvonne approached the course tutor, Cynthia Robinson, with an idea that could assist the lesaving club.In a joint collaboration, a number of lesaving signs and signals were consolidated into a Makaton course specic to lesaving.Yvonne said: ldquoWe are trying to offer inclusiveness within our sport, so we fully understand and appreciate the need for Makaton training.ldquoWe have a team of  senior and junior volunteer coaches, with an additional eight parent helpers, delivering our lesaving skill to approximately  local young people ages from six years up.ldquoWe have had great satisfaction knowing that we can try to reach out to all.Downpatrick School of Lesaving would like to thank Cynthia for her help and support..prettyPhoto

title: Sinn Fein leader McDonald visits Downpatrick
story: SINN Fein president Mary Lou McDonald was in Downpatrick on Monday as part of a visit to the district ahead of tomorrowrsquos local government election.She was welcomed to the town by party representative Oonagh Hanlon and visited the Pepper Johns Community Centre in Church Avenue and the grave of United Irishman Thomas Russell in the grounds of Down Parish Church.The Sinn Fein party leader also visited the grave of St Patrick at Down Cathedral where she met the Dean of Down, the Very Rev Henry Hull, and Dr Tim Campbell, Director of the St Patrick Centre, which is dedicated to Irelandrsquos patron saint.Accompanying the Sinn Fein president were South Down MP Chris Hazzard, Emma Rogan MLA and council election candidates Jordan Madden, who is standing in the Downpatrick DEA with Mrs Hanlon, and Slieve Croobrsquos Cathy Mason.Mrs Hanlon said she was delighted to welcome the party president to Downpatrick where she enjoyed the ldquovery unique and enduring heritage the local area has to offer, also meeting a wide range of local community leaders.ldquoI want to especially thank Alison and everyone at Pepper Johns Community Centre who made Mary Lou feel very welcome. She was clearly in awe at the fantastic work they do for the local community, said Mrs Hanlon.ldquoThanks also to Dean Hull for hosting an extremely engaging visit to Down Cathedral and the world renowned grave of St Patrick.Mrs Hanlon added: ldquoLocal people are understandably very proud of the rich, enduring Patrician heritage in these parts and itrsquos great to see such enthusiasm from yet another national political figure following the recent visit of Taacutenaiste Simon Coveney..prettyPhoto

title: Sizzling Down lift All Ireland title
story: A VIRTUOSO attacking display from Sorcha McCartan and a defensive masterclass from team captain Blanaid Savage enabled Down to lt the All-Ireland B Shield at a cold and wind-swept Inniskeen Grattans, Monaghan, on Saturday afternoon.The final scoreline was a bit rough on a game Meath outfit and two goals from the predatory Saoirse Sands, in as many minutes just before the break, proved the dference between the sides.Down started in a hurry with midfielders Megan OrsquoBoyle and Anna McKee seeing plenty of the ball and they wasted no time in getting their forwards involved.As early as the second minute, Down were awarded a free on the m line.Everyone thought that McCartan would just pop the sliotar over the bar for an easy point, but she had other ideas and blasted a fiercely-hit shot to the back of the net.Down continued to ask all the early questions, but two minutes later they were found wanting at the back and when their defence failed to deal with a Jessica Potterton free, Ciara Foley swooped to bring the sides level with an instinctive finish.McCartan edged Down back in front with a well-taken point, but two unanswered scores, one from the diligent Potterton and one from Sonia Leonard gave Meath a - to - lead after  minutes.That lead didnrsquot last long as the inspirational McCartan effortlessly lofted over a rsquo to level the scores yet again with  minutes gone.Meath were wining a lot of lsquodirty ballrsquo in the engine room, but superb defensive play from Savage and Orlaith OrsquoRourke kept them at bay.However, Potterton converted another free in the st minute to give her side a - to - lead and when Emer Fagan stretched that lead to two points, Down suddenly looked vulnerable.With  minutes gone Bredaghrsquos Aoibhinn Brentnall reduced the leeway before sizzling Sands stunned Meath.Her first goal came in the th minute after the Meath lsquokeeper was unable to clear a lofted effort from Beth Fitzpatrick. Sands struck with all the stealth and power that her dad Noel displayed for Down hurlers for many years as she beat Katie Smith all ends up with a clinical finish.Meath were now on the ropes and Sands delivered a second knock-out blow a minute later when she again ghosted in to direct a McCartan pass to the net and give down a - to - interval lead.Meath had the wind advantage after the break, but it was Down and the unrelenting McCartan who took centre stage.Two sensational points from the Castlewellan teenager, a daughter of former Down All-Ireland medal winner Greg in , stretched Downrsquos lead to seven points with only five minutes of the second half played.All credit to Meath, they steadfastly refused to throw in the towel and a Foley point left them trailing - to - after  minutes.It wax at this stage that Savage played a real captainrsquos role from her central half back role. She was simply imperious, plucking the sliotar out of the air and then sending it forward for her team-mates to chase.Meath went close to giving Down a fright in the rd minute when an explosive shot from Fagan rattled off the crossbar and was cleared to safety, but other than that, little got past Savage.McCartan and Leonard swapped points as the game drew to a close, but Down had no intention of relinquishing their grip on the game and refused to give Meath any more scores.Down: Niamh Sharkey, Orlaith OrsquoRourke, Hannah Toner, Alice Coulter, Isabella OrsquoHare, Blanaid Savage, Niamh Dempster, Megan OrsquoBoyle, Anna McKee, Cerys Clarke, Sorcha McCartan , Saoirse Sands , Gerra McGrattan, Aoibhinn Brentnall , Beth Fitzpatrick. Subs: Aimee Mallon for Toner, Toner for OrsquoRourke, Alanna Hagan for McGrattan, Colleen McConnell, Bronagh Donaghy, Olivia Blaney, Eden Casey, Hannah Duffy, Roisin McPolin, Niamh Burns, Chloe McConville, Caitlin Fitzpatrick, Aoe McCann.Meath: Katie Smith, Caitlin Hamilton, Abbye Donnelly, Sophie Healy, Kate Smith, Aine Cooke, Hazel OrsquoReilly-Higgins, Ellen Brogan, Jessica Potterton , Sonia Leonard , Emer Fagan , Rachael Fraughan, Ellen OrsquoHara, Ciara Foley , Taylor Stack. Subs: Andrea McBride for Brogan, Francesca McKenna for Fraughan.  Down -Meath -ALL-IRELAND MINOR B SHIELD FINAL.prettyPhoto

title: St John’s GAC charity fashion show
story: A FASHION show which evokes the glamorous style worn by your mother or grandmother in the s visits the area on Saturday night.St Johnrsquos GAC in Drumnaquoile is hosting the show from the Living Vintage Company as a fundraiser in aid of local people travelling to Romania with Habitat for Humanity and the Centre for Cancer Research and Cell Biology at QUB.Living Vintage is a travelling fashion show where models wear a magnicent collection of some of the most stylish haute couture of the forties and fties in a great atmosphere of fun and nostalgia.Owned by sisters Bridget Owens and Marian Keenan, Living Vintage is a not-for-profit organisation.All monies raised are donated to Cancer Research at Queens University Belfast and Habitat for Humanity.The evening will showcase day dresses, suits and evening wear and is rounded of with a stunning bridal show.Bridget said: ldquoLiving Vintage evenings are great fun with plenty of laughs and many happy nostalgic memories.ldquoWe are extremely proud of our collection of authentic forties and fties fashion and all the outfits are accessorised with the appropriate vintage hats, gloves, bags, jewellery and of course, seamed stockings. Of course, some local ladies will also be on the catwalk.Doors open .pm for show at . and tickets are available from Smythrsquos shop, Newcastle, and JRrsquoS, Main St Castlewellan or by ringing Alicia on   and Marianne on  ..prettyPhoto

title: Strictly dancing at Newcastle school
story: A NEWCASTLE primary school are to host a Strictly Come Dancing fundraiser to help raise money for the school.St Maryrsquos Primary School will be staging the night at Slieve Donard Resort and Spa next Saturday, May .Q Radiorsquos Ryan A promises to bring a pinch of razzmatazz to the dance extravaganza as hersquoll be acting as compere for the evening.Dancers include teachers, classroom assistants, parents and past pupils. There will be two fabulous dance demonstrations from European Argentina Tango champions, Anna Arriza DrsquoEste and Marco de Camillis, and  Irish dancing world champions Orlaith Bradley and David Carberry.Jenni Maguire, a teacher at the school, has been putting the dancers through their paces along with former All-Ireland Ballroom champion and choreographer Graham Jack.The event promises to be a great night of entertainment, says Graham,with demonstrations from the world champion Irish dancers to kick start the night followed by couples taking to the stage with a selection of Latin and ballroom dances.He said: ldquoI am really excited about our event. It is a great opportunity to bring the school and community together for what promises to be a real dance spectacular, while raising money for our school.ldquoI couldnrsquot do what these dancers have done. They deserve great credit for putting two dance routines together in such a short period of time.ldquoThe contestants seem to have enjoyed the build up. While there has been pressure due to the time scale in preparation and the work load involved, there have been no tears or tantrums.He added. ldquoThe practices have been good fun. There have been plenty of laughs. The iniduals and couples mix well and we all get on the best. But when the hard work needs to be done, they take it very seriously.Jenni said the couples have put in many hours of rehearsals, given freely of their time and have shown great dedication.She said: ldquoSome have revealed much hidden talent in rehearsals and head judge, UTVrsquos Rita Fitzgerald, will have a tough job on her hands but with the help of the  and votes by the audience on the night the Strictly Ball could be a closely fought battle.One of the contestants, Claire Toner, whose son Dylan is a P pupil at the school, said: ldquoI volunteered as I wanted to do something dferent. It was a case of challenging myself and trying something fun and exciting.One person who has taken it all in her stride is classroom assistant Rachel Lowey. A past pupil of the school, she is paired with another former pupil and friend Shane Kearney.She said: ldquoLike Claire, I wanted to learn something new. Never in a million years did I think Irsquod be dancing on the same stage as some of my old teachers and classroom assistants.None of the dancers have experienced formal dance training before and for some it has been very dficult attending the twice weekly rehearsals.ldquoAs enjoyable as itrsquos been, one Strictly is my limit, said school principal Philip Fusco. ldquoWe hope this will be a superb event, not just for the school community of St Maryrsquos.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming everyone on the night and I have no doubt every guest will leave with a spring in their step.Tickets are available from the school office and are priced at pound for adult sand pound concession. You can also show your support and make a donation through JustGiving page.Many of the businesses, parents, friends and family have already shown their support by sponsoring a dancer. The school would like to express their heartfelt gratitude for their support.Sponsors include: McKeeverrsquos Chemist, Property Directions, ActiSport, Nutty Chef, Cocorsquos, Quinnrsquos, Diamond Patrsquos, Smallrsquos Body Repair and Paintworx, ADS Mechanical Ltd, DTS Plumbing and Heating, Mortgage and Insurance Directions, Mark Samuel Haulage, Kelly Brothers Building Contractors, Medicare, Donard Wines, Tap Room in the Donard Bar, Matthew Toner Electrics  Lick Gelato, Joe Quality Meats, Fitzpatrickrsquos Car and Commercial Repair, ADHD Parent Support Group, Shimna Cafe, Protamino Nutrition Ltd, Blue Beans and BodyRox..prettyPhoto

title: Vandals target playground days after opening
story: THOUGHTLESS vandals have been criticised for damaging play equipment at a recently refurbished play park at the Westlands estate in Crossgar.Community worker Paul Teggart and Rowallane councillors Terry Andrews and Patrick Brown are angry that literally within days of the new facility being opened the equipment was needlessly damaged.Mr Teggart, who worked hard to persuade Newry, Mourne and Down Council to upgrade a previously dilapidated play facility at the estate, said what happened had left him lost for words.ldquoThe new play facility was opened on Tuesday of last week an damaged just a matter of days later. This senseless vandalism has to stop and stop now, he declared.ldquoThe play equipment was specically designed for small children and it is my understanding that the names of people who were spotted in the vicinity of the playground when it was vandalised have been handed over to the authorities.Mr Teggart said Crossgar was a village proud of its mixed community with people getting on well together and working in unison to make it a welcoming and vibrant place.ldquoWe all get along with each other but it would appear that there are several youths who are determined to cause harm and have no respect for anyone or indeed young childrenrsquos play equipment, he continued.Mr Teggart added: ldquoWestlands residents are rightly upset with one suggesting to me that whoever was responsible should be made to pay for the damage they have caused.Cllr Andrews said this ldquowanton act of vandalism was totally out of order and uncalled for, emphasising that it was children who suffered as a result of the ldquodespicable action of others.ldquoI have made local council officials aware of what happened and and hope that the damaged equipment can be replaced. I was proud to see a play park which had been neglected for years rejuvenated, but the damage to the equipment is so disappointing.Cllr Andrews said he had many good memories of growing up in Westlands, explaining that after years of having nothing, it was ldquowonderful to see the play park rejuvenated for so many to enjoy.He continued: ldquoI hope those responsible will be apprehended. The message must go out that this kind of behaviour will not be tolerated.Cllr Andrews said many people worked hard to persuade the local council to redevelop the Westlands play park and are bitterly disappointed that their commitment and dedication to the local community is not shared by others.Cllr Brown said he was ldquoshocked to learn that play equipment had been damaged describing those responsible as ldquothoughtless vandals.He continued: ldquoAll councillors worked hard to deliver this upgraded play park for the community and to see it so needlessly damaged in the first week it has been open is so disappointing and adds to the ongoing anti-social behaviour problem in Crossgar.Cllr Brown said he met with Mr Teggart at the play park to inspect the damage and discuss how the local authority and PSNI can stop such ldquoreckless behaviour in the future.He added: ldquoThis sort of action cannot continue and those responsible will be held accountable..prettyPhoto

title: Voters take to the polls
story: VOTERS go to the polls across the district tomorrow to elect  councillors to Newry, Mourne and Down Council.Seventy one candidates are contesting the seats up for grabs in the Downpatrick, Rowallane, Slieve Croob, Mournes, Crotlieve, Slieve Gullion and Newry areas.With the final day of canvassing already underway and candidates targeting any remaining undecided voters, all eyes will be on the magical turnout number which could decide success or failure for some.Turnout in the  council election was just over % which saw almost , people visiting polling stations across the district.As the local council prepares for its second four year term, Sinn Fein and the SDLP will be battling to become the largest party and it is certainly all to play for.Both parties currently have  councillors with Sinn Fein sources quietly confident that the party will have increased its number of seats once the final result has been declared.What is clear is that the final outcome of tomorrowrsquos election is the toughest to call in decades given the number of interesting battles taking place right across the district.Locally, all eyes will be on Downpatrick, Rowallane, Slieve Croob and The Mournes which are intriguing to say the least, with the outcome potentially resulting in a dramatic change in the political landscape and some high profile figures losing out.In Downpatrick, attention will centre on the battle between Sinn Fein and the SDLP for electoral supremacy in an area where five seats are available.The SDLPrsquos Dermot Curran, Gareth Sharvin and John Trainor are out to retain their seats, with Sinn Fein aiming to ensure that Oonagh Hanlon and Jordan Madden will secure seats on the local authority for the first time.However, Independent councillor Cadogan Enright firmly intends to retain his seat, with strong support from a number of leading community groups in Downpatrick and Lecale.Add Aontuacute , the Green Party , Alliance , the DUPand UUPinto the mix and the expected dog fight for the fth seat could well be decided by transfers.In Rowallane, Independent candidate Martyn Todd and Sinn Feinrsquos Marianne Cleary will try to upset the current status quo in an area where the five seats are shared between the DUP, UUP, SDLP and Alliance.Sinn Fein has never held a seat in Rowallane before, but clinching one in a traditional unionist stronghold would represent a seismic sht.The SDLPrsquos Terry Andrews topped the Rowallane poll in , but was only  votes ahead of the UUPrsquos Robert Burgess, who is confident his running mate, Walter Lyons, who polled  first preference votes five years ago, can join him in the debating chamber.Lyons is the only Ballynahinch-based candidate contesting the poll, with DUP sources confident that Billy Walker and Harry Harvey will retain their seats. But with no TUV candidate, what will the  voters who backed Philip Hamilton in  do this time around Independent candidate Todd is expected to eat into sitting Alliance councillorrsquos Patrick Brownrsquos vote, with the Green Party intent on making an impression through Emma Cairns. Aontuacutersquos Liam Mulhern is contesting his first election and with  candidates chasing five seats the election count will be a particularly nervous affair.In Slieve Croob, the SDLP is keen to grab two of the five seats up for grabs with current encumbent Mark Murnin, the local councilrsquos current chairman, joined by party stalwart Hugh Gallagher.Sinn Fein has made its intention clear by fielding three candidates. Republicans currently hold two seats through Roacuteisiacuten Howell and John Rice and are aiming to ensure through the partyrsquos tried and trusted vote management system that Drumaness woman Cathy Mason will also secure a seat.Sitting DUP councillor Garth Craig is not seeking re-election with the party selecting Maynard Hanna to defend his seat, while Alan Lewis is flying the flag for the Ulster Unionists.Alliance currently hold a seat in Slieve Croob through Andy McMurray but he surprised many byopting to stand in the Mournes area, with his position being contested by university graduate Gregory Bain from Clough.The Mournes is another intriguing battleground where former South Down Ulster Unionist MLA Harold McKee is bidding to make ato local politics and the SDLP is aiming toits sitting councillors, Laura Devlin and Brian Quinn.However, Sinn Fein has an eye on one of the SDLP seats and is fielding three candidates, sitting councillors Willie Clarke and Sean Doran alongside Leanne McEvoy.Henry Reilly topped the poll in  while standing on a UKIP ticket. title: ballinamallard supporters pulling out the stops for cup final
story: Trans-Atlantic trips, cancelled plane tickets, hopping back and forth across the Irish Sea. Just some of the trips and sacrices that are being made by Mallards supporters to ensure they are in Windosr Park for the biggest game in the clubrsquos history this Saturday.Kick off in the Irish Cup final is at .pm and the stands will be rocking with Mighty Duck supporters dreaming of the sweetest end to what has been an incredible journey.And speaking of journeys there are plenty being made this week. Former Ballinamallard manager Whitey Anderson boarded a plane in America, where he coaches soccer now, and has landed for the big day.ldquoIt is an occasion not to be missed for anyone involved in Ballinamallard, past or present. To get to a final is just fantastic and it is a two horse race now, he said.ldquoBest wishes to Harry and the back room team and all the players. I always liked managing at Windsor, we actually beat Linfield three times in four years there. To win a cup final would just be unbelievable and a great reward for everyone at the club for all the hard work that goes on.Another Ballinamallard fan who is flying across water is Stephen Armstrong. He hasnrsquot got as far to travel as Whitey as he lives in England but a four hour car journey has to be made to Newcastle before making his flight.A family wedding for his we meant that Stephen was earmarked for baby sitting duties. But a clash with the Mallardsrsquo big day meant some creative thinking was needed, and he found it in the shape of fellow Ballinamallard supporter Scott Williams.Scott lives in Newcastle and his we has kindly agreed to take charge of the two Amrstrong kids, along with her own two kids, for the weekend while her husband and Stephen head across the Irish Sea.ldquoIt is very good of her to let us go off gallivanting for the weekend, Stephen explained, before adding.ldquoWe are due to stay in Belast on Saturday night butballinamallard win it will be hard to resist a trip down the road.Someone better tell Mrs Williams she could have the kids for an extra night!Football writer and UEFA Communications consultant, Laure James, fell in love with the Mallards while covering them the season they were promoted to the Premiership back in . She posted a picture on twitter this week in her Ballinamallard top saying she was ldquobooking flights.Marshall Gillespie, another Fermanagh native who lives in England, and a renowned football statistician is also making his way home for the big day. For a lover of football history a chance to see the first Irish Cup final involving a Fermanagh team was something not to be missed with Marshall tweeting ldquoItrsquos going to be a quare day at Windsor!!Finally, one person very close to the squad has had to rebook flights for a wedding abroad. Mark McConkey, son of manager Harry, and a former player for Ballinamallard wasnrsquot going to miss the chance to see his dad manage a team in the Irish Cup final.ldquoIt is a once in a letime thing. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. three places to Arlene Fosters right at the DUP manesto launch earlier this monthAlthough the two were never formally linked, it was the church which provided not just many of the early DUP candidates, but also the foot soldiers who enthusiastically campaigned for the upstart party which would smash Northern Ireland’s political establishment.There were always criticisms from some in both church and party who saw the tension between a secular party with ambitions of winning votes and a fundamentalist church with the aim of saving souls.But those largely lay below the surface until Paisley’s decision to enter government with Sinn Fein, something which dismayed many in the church, who had been taught to view Sinn Fein in theological terms as the representatives of evil. The church gave Paisley an ultimatum: Choose to remain as moderator or remain as first minister. He opted for the latter and, after  years, was replaced as moderator.In his blistering valedictory interview with Eamonn Mallie in , Paisley said that his church critics “do not have the ear of God on this matter [power-sharing with Sinn Fein]”, a claim which appeared almost sacrilegious to some within the church. He also said that his family no longer entered his former church – although his son Kyle remains a Free Presbyterian cleric in England.Then in December  the church criticised the party for allowing retrospective pardons of those convicted of homosexual offences to pass through the Assembly. In implicit praise of the DUP’s nemesis, the church said that the proposal “was opposed only by Mr Allister of the TUV while sadly many others remained silent”. The church said it was “deeply grieved and bitterly disappointed” at the failure of MLAs to oppose the pardons.Now the uneasy relationship between a party which sees the strategic value in secularising and a church which believes that God’s law is unchangeable have ed with the DUP’s choice of Alison Bennington, a lesbian, as one of its council candidates. Ms Bennington has said she is standing “based on what I can deliver as a councillor ... not based on my sexual orientation”, and it is clear that the party leadership has endorsed what in any other party would be a fairly unremarkable stance.Ms Bennington was chosen centrally by the party, itself an indication that the party was taking a strategic decision to test the waters with its supporters. But for a party which once campaigned under the banner ‘Save Ulster from sodomy’ for homosexuality to remain a criminal offence, it is nevertheless a striking indication of how the DUP is changing.Traditionalist DUP MLA Jim Wells, who is currently suspended by the party, has been outspoken about what he described as a hint of “a major – and very worrying – change in the policy of the DUP on social issues”.On Saturday, TUV leader Jim Allister said he was struck in canvassing “by the number of lelong DUP voters dismayed by what they see as their party’s softening on the gay marriage issue because of the Bennington nomination”.Mr Wells yesterday said that “many, many DUP members up to the highest level”, including MPs, MLAs and former ministers, had been in contact with him to express concern about the issue because it was “a huge change in the ethos and tradition of the DUP”.Free Presbyterian sadness at the political normalisation of relations that contravene Scripture Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BELF | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BELF | Article Teaser"The South Down MLA said that there was concern within the party that it was “a step towards other radical change” and that people who had in some cases been members of the party for  years “simply cannot come to terms with this decision”.At the weekend, DUP veteran John Carson, posted on Facebook about the decision. The Ballymena councillor, who is standing for re-election on Thursday, said that he had been aDUP member for  years but “I say quite openly and with no fear of the consequences ‘NOT IN MY NAME’. I first entered politics because of my admiration for Dr Ian RK Paisley and ... I make no apologies to anyone for saying I am an old Paisleyite.”He went on: “I believe in the coming days not only myself but many of us will have some soul-searching to do and some tough decisions to make”. Invoking images of Old Testament idolatry, Mr Carson asked people to pray for wisdom for “those of us who have not bowed the knee to baal” as they “stand against evil in these days”.On Saturday, the presbytery officers of the Free Presbyterian Church issued a statement which was unusually oblique for a denomination known for its full-frontal assaults on those it regards as acting sinfully. The statement, a clear response to the DUP move, did not name the party but said that it “underlines its opposition to all marital and sexual relationships outside the covenant of Biblical marriage”.It added: “Therefore, as a church we are saddened by the attempts of political parties to normalise and promote marital and sexual relationships that are in contravention of the clear teaching of Scripture.”The statement was read out in some Free Presbyterian churches on Sunday, although not in others, in what may be a hint of the church – as well as the party – being split on the issue.Although a tiny denomination, Free Presbyterianism has long exerted an influence which exceeds its size, both through the DUP and its frequent pronouncements to the media about issues of public morals.One church source said that there was a desire among some within the congregation to see DUP party officers who are members of the church disciplined for their role in Ms Bennington’s selection.In response to the church’s statement, the DUP merely said: “Our position on support for traditional marriage is well known and as the party leader indicated last week, it has not changed.”An academic study, published as the book The Democratic Unionist Party: From Protest To Power, four years ago found that the Free Presbyterian Church continued to wield huge influence within the party, with % of DUP members being Free Presbyterian. That meant that Free Presbyterians were  times more common in the DUP than in the population.It has been clear for some time that the DUP is no longer “the DUP at prayer”. If this is the first time you have subscribed to emails from JPIMedia Ltd, the publishers of Belfast Newsletter, please check your inbox to very your email address.  .html.valThe government has outlined details of a # million-plus funding package for Londonderry.The investment is made up of £ million in funding for the Derry and Strabane City Deal and £ million of additional support through a new Inclusive Future Fund aimed at tackling deprivation and employment issues in the city.The government had already signalled its intent to part-finance a city investment deal similar to the agreement secured by Belfast. The government has committed £ million to the Belfast city deal.The Londonderry package was announced ahead of today’s new round of Stormont talks aimed at restoring power-sharing in Northern Ireland.It comes weeks after the dissident republican murder of journalist Lyra McKee in the city. Many believe the extremists are exploiting disaffection and deprivation experienced by young people in parts of the city to bolster their ranks.Northern Ireland Secretary Karen Bradley said the Derry City and Strabane City Deal would boost innovation and the digital potential of the region and unlock local partner funding.She said it would enable new projects such as a Centre for Industrial Digitisation, Robotics and Automation and a programme of investment in the city’s digital connectivity infrastructure – subject to business case approval.“This £ million investment package is a major boost to the economic potential of the region and will help strengthen the foundations for greater prosperity and a stronger, more united society,” she said.“The new Inclusive Future Fund recognises the unique circumstances facing the region and will help create new opportunities for the whole of the community, especially for young people.“As secretary of state, I am deeply committed to building a dynamic, prosperous, outward-looking Northern Ireland that works for everyone, irrespective of community background.”The money offered through the Inclusive Future Fund will focus on delivering title: vale council caves in to arrogant dog owners over proposals to keep off sport pitches
story: Vale of Glamorgan Council has said a blanket ban on sports pitches will not be included in a proposed public spaces protection orderaimed at stopping anti-social dog walkers.Dog walkers would face fines of poundthey do not pick up their petsrsquo faeces at sports pitches or other public spaces, and there would also be seasonal bans on some beaches.The sports pitch ban was dropped following public opposition as a petition signed by , people opposed the move.But a consultation answered by , people found per cent supported the banning of dogs from marked sports pitches.Councillor Kevin Mahoney told the councilrsquos Environment and Regeneration Scrutiny Committee on April  that a blanket ban of dogs from sports pitches was the authorityrsquos ldquoone chance to deal with the issue of fouling on sports pitches.He said the ldquosheer arrogance of people to think they should demand that their dogs can go on sports pitches is ldquoabsolutely disgraceful.He added: ldquoIrsquove heard people whining theyrsquove got nowhere to walk their dog, but thatrsquos strange because Irsquom a dog owner and I donrsquot have any problem with that.ldquoItrsquos impossible to clear the complete amount of faeces left by even those so-called responsible dog owners.ldquoThis authority has admitted year after year itrsquos physically incapable of policing dog fouling.The one chance you have of keeping faeces off sports pitches is having a blanket ban so that any dog on there, the owner can be prosecuted.ldquoWho on earth do they think they are  These members of the public who have been so indignant and insistent their dogs should be allowed to do this  And who on earth are the Vale cabinet to agree with them and back down in this way He said the cabinet are ldquocaving into a bunch of indignant dog owners who, quite frankly,they canrsquot find anywhere to walk their dog as I do, they shouldnrsquot own a dog.Seasonal bans of dogs from Penarth seafront and the Knap beach are also set to be removed but dog bans will still apply on a seasonal basis at Whitmore Bay, Dunraven Bay and Cwm Colhuw.Dogs would still be banned from all childrenrsquos play areas, ecological conservation areas and bowling greens in the Vale, and they would be required to be on leads all year round onthe promenade at Whitmore Bay and Penarth seafront and pier.RSPCA Cymru opposed the sports pitch ban but agreed it should be an offence for dog owners not to clean up after their pets.Council leader John Thomas has previously said the council has taken peoplersquos views into account and has achieved a ldquobalanced position.Cllr Lis Burnett told the committee that dog owners had felt victimised by the proposals.ldquoItrsquos been so painful getting here, she said. ldquoIt was so painful for many members of the public who felt they were earmarked for derision as dog owners or dog walkers.ldquoWe need to learn from this exercise and understand that consultation is not engagement. So many people say lsquowhy wonrsquot the council talk to us "Cllr Steffan William askedsports pitches could be ldquofenced off to prevent dogs walking on them, but the councilrsquos operational manager Colin Smith said this ldquocould be quite costly for the council.At the start of the meeting, Mr Smith said: ldquoWe know the majority of dog owners are responsible and we donrsquot want to limit them from the green spaces the Vale has to offer.There were also calls for more dog waste bins throughout the Vale at the meeting.Councillors heard there have been just six prosecutions for dog fouling in the Vale of Glamorgan in the past year.Cardf councilrsquos PSPO against dog fouling will see dog owners fined poundtheyrsquore found without bags or the means of picking up after their pets.But Mr Smith said: ldquoThe legal team were concerned it wouldnrsquot be lawful. title: view from westminster stephen doughty
story: Last Wednesday, MPs had the opportunity to participate in indicative votes on ious Brexit-related motions.This unusual step came after an amendment was passed securing parliamentary time for debate and a series of votes on Brexit scenarios, to see which,any, might command a majority in the House of Commons.Following this, on Friday the Prime Minister brought her botched deal back to the house again, after what can only be described as political lsquotrickery of the highest orderrsquo.But yet again she was defeated, this time by  votes.This was another huge defeat despite increasingly desperate efforts by the Government to try and cajole people in the last few hours before the vote.I am not prepared to support a blindfold Brexit - so I voted NO. Surely it should be three strikes and out for this deal now And so on Monday, further indicative votes were held as MPs once again took control of parliamentary business ndash despite attempts by the government to shut down our debate before it started.Supporting the move to hold these further indicative votes on Monday, I said: ldquoI think Parliament made remarkable progress the other day in a few hours, compared with the Government, who have had two years to sort this out."It is important that we not only have the opportunity to make further progress tonight, but,necessary, a small amount of time on Wednesday to get to where we need to be, so that Parliament can take control and we can move forward together as a House.And so on Monday evening, there was a hugely signicant result placing a Peoplersquos Vote as the top option for resolving the impasse, with a Customs Union only narrowly missing out as well.I voted the same way as I did last week ndash for a Customs Union for a Peoplersquos Vote, and to revoke Article we face a No Deal Brexit.Itrsquos time for the PM to compromise for the good of the country.We all need to work together to find a solution.We need a credible Brexit option to be put to a public vote in a final say, with the option on the ballot paper to Remain, in order to find a way through this crisis. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: view from the senedd vaughan gething
story: That date has come and gone.Instead we now face the real possibility of crashing out of the EU without a deal on Friday April .We are still no closer to determining what our relationship with Europe will look like than we were two years ago.Understandably, I have been contacted by a number of constituents who look at the shambles in Westminster and just want to know what is going on.Since my last update Parliament has twice rejected Theresa Mayrsquos Brexit deal by large majorities.MPs have taken control of business in Westminster and the UK Government is openly fighting with itself.On Monday MPs debated for the second time alternative visions for Brexit.The proposals to stay in the Customs Union and for a confirmatory public vote had the greatest support ndash and more support than Theresa Mayrsquos deal ndash but nothing had a majority.The choice of the UK Government to run down the clock have made the prospect of leaving the EU without a deal more likely.Theresa Mayrsquos deal is plainly not going through Parliament but no deal is even more unpalatable.A lsquoNo Dealrsquo Brexit would be bad for Wales and bad for jobs here in Cardf South and Penarth.Manufacturers, trade unions and a wide range of businesses have told us that jobs and livelihoods are at risk.We have already seen that the threat of Brexit is a real factor in jobs that have already left the UK.An industry study has warned that should we leave with no deal it could result in a loss of , jobs, with , of these jobs in Wales.It would cost the jobs of families that I represent.In my government role I have met with health and social care leaders to discuss the impact of a no deal Brexit and to plan our response.We want to ensure an uninterrupted supply of medication and secure the rights of EU nationals working within Wales.Last week I announced the acquisition of a warehouse in south Wales to provide additional storage health and care equipment to ensure there is a continuity of supply for Wales.The Welsh Government has also set up a Business Wales portal to help businesses in Wales prepare for Brexit.It has also created a poundmillion fund to help businesses prepare for the challenges of Brexit.I would urge businesses in Cardf South and Penarth to visit the Business Wales portal and find out about the support that is available.However all of our preparations cannot remove the risk of disruption.A no deal would be highly damaging for our health and care system and the people who rely upon it.I cannot overstate how much time energy and effort has been soaked up in preparing for a No Deal instead of improving our health and care system.No Deal is not a consequence free choice.It is a scandalous waste of our resources and the commitment of our staff.Politicians who bravely talk about a managed No Deal have not had to confront the realities of preparing for it or the scale of waste and damage it would cause.The most troubling aspect of Brexit has been that the isions within the UK are growing.For all my disappointment, Parliament is not enemy territory, as Nigel Farage claimed. That anger and stoking of ision is dangerous and irresponsible.At that same rally we saw a leader of the far right who is a convicted violent racist criminal being applauded on stage.That should not make any us proud regardless of how we voted.The biggest threat to the union of the UK comes from a No Deal.It would not only destabilise politics in Northern Ireland but it would almost certainly guarantee another Scottish independence referendum.More turmoil that would not turn back the tide of austerity or add a single extra penny into our schools, the NHS or any other public service that we rely upon.I do not believe a ided UK Parliament can make a choice for the next generation of our ided countries.I was proud to sponsor two coaches and march alongside more than a million members of the public, including many people from Cardf South and Penarth calling for a Peoplersquos Vote.We need to go back to the people with a choice between a Brexit deal that Parliament can agree and our current deal within the EU.There is no simple choice to the isions that we face but I would as ever be interested to hear views from my constituents. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... story: That date has come and gone.Instead we now face the real possibility of crashing out of the EU without a deal on Friday April .We are still no closer to determining what our relationship with Europe will look like than we were two years ago.Understandably, I have been contacted by a number of constituents who look at the shambles in Westminster and just want to know what is going on.Since my last update Parliament has twice rejected Theresa Mayrsquos Brexit deal by large majorities.MPs have taken control of business in Westminster and the UK Government is openly fighting with itself.On Monday MPs debated for the second time alternative visions for Brexit.The proposals to stay in the Customs Union and for a confirmatory public vote had the greatest support ndash and more support than Theresa Mayrsquos deal ndash but nothing had a majority.The choice of the UK Government to run down the clock have made the prospect of leaving the EU without a deal more likely.Theresa Mayrsquos deal is plainly not going through Parliament but no deal is even more unpalatable.A lsquoNo Dealrsquo Brexit would be bad for Wales and bad for jobs here in Cardf South and Penarth.Manufacturers, trade unions and a wide range of businesses have told us that jobs and livelihoods are at risk.We have already seen that the threat of Brexit is a real factor in jobs that have already left the UK.An industry study has warned that should we leave with no deal it could result in a loss of , jobs, with , of these jobs in Wales.It would cost the jobs of families that I represent.In my government role I have met with health and social care leaders to discuss the impact of a no deal Brexit and to plan our response.We want to ensure an uninterrupted supply of medication and secure the rights of EU nationals working within Wales.Last week I announced the acquisition of a warehouse in south Wales to provide additional storage health and care equipment to ensure there is a continuity of supply for Wales.The Welsh Government has also set up a Business Wales portal to help businesses in Wales prepare for Brexit.It has also created a poundmillion fund to help businesses prepare for the challenges of Brexit.I would urge businesses in Cardf South and Penarth to visit the Business Wales portal and find out about the support that is available.However all of our preparations cannot remove the risk title: victoria primary pupils clean penarth beach after inspiring visit
story: As a part of their science topic of Habitats, Year Three pupils from Victoria Primary School, Penarth recently had a visit from the National Marine Aquarium.The aquarium held several fascinating workshops for the children to take part in.The aquarium made use of cutting-edge technology, including Virtual Reality headsets.Using the headsets, the children were able to lsquoersquo more than m down into the ldquoMidnight Zone.The Midnight Zone is one of the deepest, darkest areas of the ocean, and the children had the chance to see the predators and their prey in action.They also explored the food chains found in the seas and oceans of our world.They further examined the impact of plastic on these food chains and their habitats.Following these workshops, Year Three decided to undertake a beach clean on Penarth beach.Equipment was loaned by Keep Wales Tidy, the Welsh environmental charity.The youngsters did exceptionally well on their beach clean, collecting three full bags of rubbish in  minutes.They discussed dferent types of rubbish found, where it could have come from and its impact on the beach habitat and the ecosystem. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: new kymin park group to guide future of venue
story: The Kymin, a house and garden overlooking the pier and popular for weddings, had been under threat due to funding constraints, as the Penarth Times previously reported.Penarth Town Council has now said the site will close next year, and will not take bookings from March .The leader of Penarth council Cllr Rhiannon Birch said: ldquoThe town council is proud to have operated The Kymin for the people of Penarth and its visitors for four decades, under a licence from the Vale of Glamorgan CouncilldquoWe had sought a more secure tenure of the site, through Community Asset Transfer or medium-long term lease.ldquoThis would have allowed the financial investment required in the venue but these approaches have been declined by the Vale council.ldquoWith no security of tenure, the council cannot commit expenditure required and has no choice but to close.ldquoWe are proud of the events and hires hosted by the building and the valuable green space it provides in Penarth.ldquoAs the council is no longer able to operate the Kymin, we are now glad to be able to offer community hire space at West House Community Hub, following the improvements to the public community garden under the Penarth in Bloom project.Vale of Glamorgan Council managing director Rob Thomas added: ldquoIt was entirely the Penarth Town Councilrsquos decision to close the building early and prior to the termination date in .ldquoThe Vale of Glamorgan Council was surprised to learn of the decision to close and leave it vacant for the rest of the notice period.ldquoThe council feels that this decision is to the detriment of those who use the site, local residents and the wider Penarth Community, but the Vale council has no power to force the town council to keep the building open,they chose not to.A group is now being set is being set up concerned residents to help guide the future of the Kymin Park.Richard Parry, a regular user of the park, has asked anyone interested in the outcome of the park to attend a meeting.Mr Parry said: "The Kymin Park is an important and lovely part of the town landscape. It is, in many ways, a hidden corner of Penarth with a unique and special character."The future plans for the house will no doubt be a subject of local interest and concern, but in the meantime a number of local people have expressed interest in forming a voluntary group called "The Friends of the Kymin Park."This group would aim to promote enjoyment of the park as public pleasure grounds."Wed also invite both councils to keep us informed of developments so that "the friends of the Kymin Park" could also be a source of good information about arrangements of access and enjoyment of the park during the time that the park management negotiations are resolved," added Mr Parry."Anyone interested is welcome to come to a meeting on Tuesday at .pm in Foxys Deli,  Victoria Road, Penarth to discuss the formation of a group "The Friends of the Kymin Park", specically focused on supporting and developing public enjoyment of the park grounds." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: residents urged to sign petition to ban all animals travelling performances ahead of circus mondao
story: Circus Mondao, a travelling showcase with trapeze artists, clowns, stunts and animals, will stop in the Vale from April  to .But a petition has been launched to ban the use of all animals in circuses in Wales, including by Circus Mondao.ldquoItrsquos just cruel, forcing animals to behave like that, said Linda Joyce Jones, who started the petition. ldquoThey donrsquot want to be there, and theyrsquore forced to travel constantly.Petra Jackson, the ringmistress, looks after the animals for Circus Mondao.ldquoWe look after the animals in our care, she said. ldquoWe follow stringent government standards and guidelines. We place our animalrsquos welfare at the top of our list, and they only make up a very small portion of the show.ldquoTheyrsquore not just animals, theyrsquore part of our family. They want for nothing with us.ldquoThey do travel, but its no more intensive than an average commuter bringing along their dog in the car.ldquoWhen we pitch up, they stay in large, custom built and comfortable enclosures. Wersquore staying at a venue in Rhoose rather than Sully this year, because it is a more secluded area which the animals prefer.Animal welfare is a devolved issue.While it is an offence under the Animal Welfare Act  to fail to provide for an animal properly, a bill will be put forward this year by the Welsh Government to ban wild animals in circuses entirely, though some animals - such as dogs or ponies - are not covered. England will introduce a similar bill in .A public consultation, carried out in Wales in November  and published in January , found that out of , responses,  per cent of responses were behind a ban on wild animals in circuses.But a total of , of these responses were identical, from campaign group Born Free.More than  local authorities in the UK have a ban on animals in circuses, but the Vale council is not among them. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice.
